conversation.content: [playful] So you've been doing makeup for what, fifteen years now?
Seventeen, actually—started when I was nineteen in a funeral home, believe it or not. Death teaches you about life; making the departed look peaceful taught me how to make the living look radiant.
That's a dark beginning.
Not dark, illuminating! See, corpses don't lie about their bone structure; they can't tense their muscles or fake expressions. You learn the architecture of a face when it's completely still.
How'd you transition to fashion?

[exhausted] Fashion found me, honestly—a photographer saw my mortuary work and said, "Anyone who can make death look that good should be working with models." Three weeks later I was backstage at Fashion Week with brushes shaking, surrounded by chaos, thinking what have I done?
[warm] But you clearly thrived.

Thriving is... a process. The living move, they sweat, they have opinions about coral versus peach. But here's the thing: makeup is sculpture with time limits—you're creating dimensional illusions that have to survive under lights, through tears, past midnight.
What's your signature technique?

I build faces like music: crescendo here, diminuendo there, staccato highlights, legato blending. Most artists paint; I compose—every face gets its own rhythm, its own tempo based on bone structure and personality.
That sounds incredibly complex.

Complex? No, it's intuitive once you understand that faces are just geography—hills, valleys, plains waiting for light and shadow. The complexity comes from reading the person inside the face; that's where the real artistry lives.
[condescending] Sure, but isn't it basically just covering flaws?

Flaws! There are no flaws, only features seeking their best light. What you call a flaw, I call character—a scar tells stories, asymmetry creates interest, texture gives depth that perfect smoothness never could.
You've worked with some huge celebrities.

Fame is irrelevant when someone's in my chair; we're all just skin and stories. Though I will say, the nervous energy of a first-time bride beats any A-lister's premiere jitters—that vulnerability is electric.
Any disasters you can share?

Oh, once I had exactly three minutes to fix a full face after a celebrity ugly-cried off everything right before walking the red carpet. Tissue, powder, precision—we made it work, and she looked luminous, tears transformed into dewy radiance.
Do you ever get tired of it?

Tired of transformation? Never. Every face is a blank canvas with infinite possibilities; every day I get to help people see themselves differently—more bold, more beautiful, more... themselves, just amplified.
